{{Hatnote|For electric music technologies, see [[Music technology (electric)]]}} [[Image:Peter Francken in his studio.jpg|thumb|300px|This 2009 photo shows music production using a [[digital audio workstation]] (DAW) with [[multi-monitor]] set-up.]] '''Electronic and digital music technology''' is the use of electronic or digital instruments, [[computer]]s, electronic [[effects unit]]s, [[software]] or [[digital audio]] equipment by a [[musician]], [[composer]], [[sound engineer]], [[DJ]] or [[record producer]] to make, perform<ref>{{cite web|last=m:tech educational services|title=What is Music Technology?|url=http://www.mtechonline.co.uk/schools/what-is-music-technology.html|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> or [[sound recording|record]] [[music]]. The term usually refers to the use of electronic devices, electronic and digital instruments, [[computer hardware]] and [[computer software]] that is used in the [[performance]], playback, [[Sound recording and reproduction|recording]], [[musical composition|composition]], [[sound recording and reproduction]], [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixing]], [[Music informatics|analysis]] and [[Digital audio editor|editing]] of music.
Music technology is connected to both artistic and technological creativity. Musicians and music technology experts are constantly striving to devise new forms of expression through music, and they are physically creating new devices and software to enable them to do so. Although in the 2010s, the term is most commonly used in reference to modern electronic devices and computer software such as [[digital audio workstation]]s and [[Protools]] digital sound recording software, electronic and digital musical technologies have precursors in the [[Music technology (electric)|electric music technologies]] of the early 20th century, such as the electromechanical [[Hammond organ]], which was invented in 1929. In the 2010s, the [[Ontology|ontological]] range of music technology has greatly increased, and it may now be electronic, digital, software-based or indeed even purely conceptual.
==Education==
===Professional training=== {{see also|Audio engineer|Category:Audio engineering schools}} Music technology is taught at many different educational levels, including college diplomas and university degrees at the undergraduate and graduate level. The study of music technology is usually concerned with the creative use of technology for creating new sounds, performing, [[Sound recording and reproduction|recording]], [[Programming (music)|programming]] [[Music sequencer|sequencers]] or other music-related electronic devices, and manipulating, mixing and reproducing music. Music technology programs train students for careers in "...sound engineering, computer music, audio-visual production and post-production, mastering, scoring for film and multimedia, audio for [[video games|games]], software development, and multimedia production."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://steinhardt.nyu.edu/music/technology|title=Music Technology - NYU Steinhardt|author=|date=|website=steinhardt.nyu.edu|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Those wishing to develop new music technologies often train to become an [[Audio engineers#Research and development|audio engineer working in R&D]].<ref name="wisegeek">{{cite web|last=wiseGeek|title=What Is Audio Engineering?|url=http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-audio-engineering.htm|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref> Due to the increasing role of interdisciplinary work in music technology, individuals developing new music technologies may also have backgrounds or training in [[computer programming]], [[computer hardware]] design, [[acoustics]], [[record producer|record producing]] or other fields.
===Use in music education=== In the 2010s, electronic and digital music technologies are widely used to assist in [[music education]] for training students in high school, college and university music programs. [[Electronic keyboard]] labs are used for cost-effective beginner group piano instruction in colleges and universities.
==History== Early pioneers included [[Luigi Russolo]], [[Halim El-Dabh]],<ref name="holmes_156">{{cite book|title=Electronic and experimental music: technology, music, and culture|first=Thom|last=Holmes|edition=3rd|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]]|year=2008|isbn=0-415-95781-8|chapter=Early Synthesizers and Experimenters|page=156|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hCthQ-bec-QC&pg=PA156|accessdate=2011-06-04}}</ref> [[Pierre Schaeffer]], [[Pierre Henry]], [[Edgard Varèse]], [[Karlheinz Stockhausen]], [[Ikutaro Kakehashi]],<ref name="fact">[http://www.factmag.com/2017/04/02/ikutaro-kakehashi-life/ The life and times of Ikutaro Kakehashi, the Roland pioneer modern music owes everything to], ''[[Fact (UK magazine)|Fact]]''</ref> and [[King Tubby]].<ref name="veal">Michael Veal (2013), [https://books.google.com/books?id=kYtiAgAAQBAJ&pg=PP54 ''Dub: Soundscapes and Shattered Songs in Jamaican Reggae'', pages 26-44, "Electronic Music in Jamaica"], [[Wesleyan University Press]]</ref> Music technology has been and is being used in many [[Modernism|modernist]] and contemporary experimental music situations to create new sound possibilities.
==Synthesizers and drum machines== [[File:R.A.Moog minimoog 2.jpg|thumb|right|An early [[Minimoog]] synthesizer by R.A. Moog Inc. from 1970.]] A [[synthesizer]] is an [[electronic musical instrument]] that generates electric signals that are converted to sound through [[instrument amplifier]]s and [[loudspeaker]]s or [[headphones]]. Synthesizers may either [[#Imitative synthesis|imitate existing sounds]] (instruments, vocal, natural sounds, etc.), or generate new electronic [[timbres]] or sounds that did not exist before. They are often played with an electronic [[musical keyboard]], but they can be controlled via a variety of other input devices, including [[music sequencers]], [[MIDI controller|instrument controllers]], [[#Fingerboard controller|fingerboards]], [[guitar synthesizer]]s, [[wind controller]]s, and [[electronic drum]]s. Synthesizers without built-in controllers are often called [[sound modules]], and are controlled using a controller device.
Synthesizers use various methods to generate a signal. Among the most popular waveform synthesis techniques are [[subtractive synthesis]], [[additive synthesis]], [[wavetable synthesis]], [[frequency modulation synthesis]], [[phase distortion synthesis]], [[physical modeling synthesis]] and [[sample-based synthesis]]. Other less common synthesis types include [[Subharmonic synthesizer|subharmonic synthesis]], a form of additive synthesis via subharmonics (used by [[Trautonium|mixture trautonium]]), and [[granular synthesis]], sample-based synthesis based on grains of sound, generally resulting in [[soundscape]]s or [[Cloud (music)|clouds]]. In the 2010s, synthesizers are used in many genres of [[pop music|pop]], [[rock music|rock]] and [[dance music]]. Contemporary [[classical music]] [[composer]]s from the 20th and 21st century write compositions for synthesizer.
The development of the modern synthesizer was spurred on by the invention of the miniaturized [[transistor]] in 1947. The lightweight transistors made it was possible to make [[synthesizer]]s much more portable and complex. A new breed of synthesizers appeared, mainly in [[America]]. American inventor [[Robert Moog]]'s [[synthesizer]] designs in the 1960s were a significant advancement in the field over its predecessors. This was partially owed to new technologies that became available, such as the [[Semiconductors|newly developed semiconductors]]. These new instruments were less expensive and became available worldwide. These were capable of producing a vast range of complex sounds. Later versions often incorporated automatic rhythm units, called [[drum machine]]s. They had more popularity than any synthesizer from the past. The release of [[Wendy Carlos]]' album ''[[Switched-On Bach]]'' in 1968 brought [[Moog synthesizer|Moog's synthesizer]] to the general public's attention. The album demonstrated that besides creating strange sounds, the [[synthesizer]] could be used to make beautiful music. [[File:Yamaha_DX7_Table_4.JPG|thumb|right|200px|The [[Yamaha DX7]].]] In the 1970s, the American domination of the synthesizer market was relinquished to the Japanese,<ref name="Musical Instruments">{{cite book | last1 = Campbell | first1 = Murray | first2 = Clive | last2 = Greated | first3 =Arnold | last3 = Myers | title = [[Musical Instruments]] | location = New York | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] }}</ref> with synthesizers made by [[Yamaha Corporation]], [[Roland Corporation]], [[Korg]], [[Kawai]] and other companies. Yamaha's [[Yamaha DX7|DX7]] was one of the first mass-market, relatively inexpensive synthesizer keyboards. The DX7 is an [[frequency modulation synthesis|FM synthesis]] based digital [[synthesizer]] manufactured from 1983 to 1989. It was the first commercially successful [[digital synthesizer]].<ref name=edmondson2013> {{cite book | editor-last = Edmondson | editor-first = Jacqueline | title = Music in American Life: An Encyclopedia of the Songs, Styles, Stars, and Stories that Shaped our Culture [4 volumes] | publisher = ABC-CLIO | publication-date = 2013 | isbn = 9780313393488 | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=TQPXAQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA398&pg=PA398&dq=DX7++first+commercially+successful+digital+synthesizer&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&f=falsee 398] | quote = ''In 1967, John Chowning, at Stanford University, accidentally discovered frequency modulation (FM) synthesis when experimenting with extreme vibrato effects in MUSIC-V. ... By 1971 he was able to use FM synthesis to synthesizer musical instrument sounds, and this technique was later used to create the Yamaha DX synthesizer, the first commercially successful digital synthesizer, in the early 1980s.'' }} </ref><ref name=shepard2013> {{cite book | last = Shepard | first = Brian K. | title = Refining Sound: A Practical Guide to Synthesis and Synthesizers | publisher = Oxford University Press | publication-date = 2013 | isbn = 9780199376681 | quote = ''The first digital synthesizer to make it into the studios of everyone else, the Yamaha DX7, became one of the most commercially successful synthesizers of all time.'' }} </ref><ref name=Pinch2003> {{cite journal | last1 = Pinch | first1 = T. J. | last2 = Bijsterveld | first2 = Karin | author-link2 = Karin Bijsterveld | title = "Should One Applaud?" Breaches and Boundaries in the Reception of New Technology in Music | url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/tech/summary/v044/44.3pinch.html | journal = Technology and Culture | volume = 44 | issue = 3 | publication-date = July 2003 | pages = 536–559 | doi = 10.1353/tech.2003.0126 | quote = ''By the time the first commercially successful digital instrument, the Yamaha DX7 (lifetime sales of two hundred thousand), appeared in 1983 ...'' }} (Note: the above sales number seems about whole DX series) </ref> Its distinctive sound can be heard on many recordings, especially [[pop music]] from the 1980s. The [[monotimbral]], 16-note [[Polyphony and monophony in instruments|polyphonic]] DX7 was the moderately priced model of the DX series keyboard synthesizers. Over 200,000 of the original DX7 were made,<ref name=Pinch2003/><ref name=Johnstone> {{cite journal | last = Johnstone | first = Robert | title = The sound of one chip clapping: Yamaha and FM synthesis | url = https://www.academia.edu/2680140/The_sound_of_one_chip_clapping_Yamaha_and_FM_synthesis | work = MIT Japan Program: Science, Technology, Management | id = MIT JP 94-09 | publisher = Center for International Studies, Massachusetts Institute of Technology }} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sonicstate.com/news/2015/01/26/namm-2015-video-yamaha-vintage-synth-museum-tour/|title=NAMM 2015: Yamaha Vintage Synth Museum Tour|author=|date=|website=sonicstate.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> and it remains one of the best-selling synthesizers of all time.<ref name=shepard2013/><ref name="holmes_257"> {{cite book | title = Electronic and experimental music: technology, music, and culture | last = Holmes| first = Thom | edition = 3rd | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]]|year=2008|isbn=0415957818|chapter=Early Computer Music|page=257|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hCthQ-bec-QC&pg=PA257 | accessdate= 2011-06-04 }}</ref> The most iconic [[bass synthesizer]] is the [[Roland TB-303]], widely used in [[Acid house|acid]] [[house music]]. Other classic synthesizers include the [[Moog Minimoog]], [[ARP Odyssey]], [[Yamaha CS-80]], [[Korg MS-20]], [[Sequential Circuits Prophet-5]], [[Fairlight CMI]], [[PPG Wave]], [[Roland TB-303]], [[Roland Alpha Juno]], [[Nord Modular]] and [[Korg M1]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Twells|first1=John|title=The 14 Synthesizers that Shaped Modern Music|url=http://www.factmag.com/2014/02/28/the-14-synthesizers-that-shaped-modern-music/|website=Fact Music News|accessdate=December 8, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306042725/http://www.factmag.com/2014/02/28/the-14-synthesizers-that-shaped-modern-music/|archivedate=2014-03-06|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Drum machines=== [[File:Yamaha RY30 front.png|thumb|A [[Yamaha]] RY30 Drum Machine]] A [[drum machine]] is an [[electronic musical instrument]] designed to imitate the [[sound]] of [[drum kit|drum]]s, [[cymbal]]s, other [[percussion instrument]]s, and often [[basslines]]. Drum machines either play back prerecorded samples of drums and cymbals or synthesized re-creations of drum/cymbal sounds in a rhythm and tempo that is programmed by a musician. Drum machines are most commonly associated with [[electronic dance music]] genres such as [[house music]], but are also used in many other genres. They are also used when [[session musician|session drummers]] are not available or if the production cannot afford the cost of a professional drummer. In the 2010s, most modern drum machines are [[music sequencer|sequencers]] with a sample playback ([[rompler]]) or [[synthesizer]] component that specializes in the reproduction of drum [[timbre]]s. Though features vary from model to model, many modern drum machines can also produce unique sounds, and allow the user to compose unique [[drum beat]]s and patterns.
Electro-mechanical drum machines were first developed in 1949, with the invention of the [[Chamberlin|Chamberlin Rhythmate]]. Transistorized electronic drum machines later appeared in the 1960s. The [[Ace Tone]] Rhythm Ace, created by [[Ikutaro Kakehashi]], began appearing in [[popular music]] from the late 1960s, followed by drum machines from [[Korg]] and Ikutaro's later [[Roland Corporation]] also appearing in popular music from the early 1970s.<ref name="sos_roland">{{citation |last=Reid |first=Gordon |year=2004 |title=The History Of Roland Part 1: 1930–1978 |journal=[[Sound on Sound]] |issue=November |url=http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/nov04/articles/roland.htm |accessdate=19 June 2011 }}</ref> [[Sly and the Family Stone]]'s 1971 album ''[[There's a Riot Goin' On]]'' helped to popularize the sound of early drum machines, along with [[Timmy Thomas]]' 1972 [[R&B]] hit "[[Why Can't We Live Together]]" and [[George McCrae]]'s 1974 [[disco]] hit "[[Rock Your Baby]]" which used early Roland rhythm machines.<ref name="collins">Mike Collins (2014), [https://books.google.com/books?id=tdEABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA320 ''In the Box Music Production: Advanced Tools and Techniques for Pro Tools'', page 320], [[CRC Press]]</ref>
Early drum machines sounded drastically different than the drum machines that gained their peak popularity in the 1980s and defined an entire decade of pop music. The most iconic drum machine was the [[Roland TR-808]], widely used in [[hip hop]] and [[dance music]]. Other classic drum machines include the [[Alesis|Alesis HR-16]], [[Korg Mini Pops|Korg Mini Pops 120]], [[E-mu|E-MU SP-12]], [[Elektron (company)|Elektron]] SPS1 Machinedrum, [[Roland CR-78]], [[PAiA Electronics|PAiA]] Programmable Drum Set, [[LinnDrum]], [[Roland TR-909]] and [[Oberheim DMX]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Felton|first1=David|title=Top Ten Classic Drum Machines|url=http://www.attackmagazine.com/features/top-ten-classic-drum-machines/|website=Attack Magazine|accessdate=December 8, 2015}}</ref>
==Sampling technology== {{see also|Sampler (musical instrument)|}}
Digital sampling technology, introduced in the 1980s, has become a staple of [[music production]] in the 2000s. Devices that use [[Sampler (musical instrument)|sampling]], record a sound digitally (often a musical instrument, such as a [[piano]] or [[flute]] being played), and replay it when a key or pad on a controller device (e.g., an [[electronic keyboard]], [[electronic drum]] pad, etc.) is pressed or triggered. Samplers can alter the sound using various [[effects unit|audio effects]] and audio processing. Sampling has its roots in [[France]] with the sound experiments carried out by [[Musique Concrete]] practitioners.
In the 1980s, when the technology was still in its infancy, digital samplers cost tens of thousands of dollars and they were only used by the top [[recording studio]]s and musicians. These were out of the price range of most musicians. Early samplers include the 12-bit [[Toshiba]] [[Technodelic|LMD-649]]<ref name="auto">''[[:nl:Rockin'f|Rockin'f]]'', March 1982, [http://tokyosky.sub.jp/tokyosky_webmasters_blog/2011/02/f-19823-lmd-649-1982.html pages 140-141]</ref> and the 8-bit [[Emulator I]] in 1981. The latter's successor, the [[Emulator II]] (released in 1984), listed for $8,000.<ref name="Electronic Music Pioneers">{{cite book | last = Kettlewell | first = Ben | author-link = | title = Electronic Music Pioneers | publisher = Pro Music Press | location = USA | date = 2002}}</ref> Samplers were released during this period with high price tags, such as the [[Kurzweil Music Systems|K2000]] and [[K2500]].
The first affordable sampler, the [[Akai|AKAI S612]], became available in the mid-1980s and retailed for US$895. Other companies soon released affordable samplers, including the [[Ensoniq Mirage|Mirage Sampler]], [[Oberheim Electronics|Oberheim DPX-1]], and more by [[Korg]], [[Casio]], [[Yamaha]], and [[Roland]]. Some important hardware samplers include the [[Akai|Akai Z4/Z8]], [[Ensoniq ASR-10]], [[Roland Corporation|Roland V-Synth]], [[Casio FZ-1]], [[Kurzweil K250]], [[Akai MPC60]], [[Ensoniq Mirage]], [[Akai S1000]], [[E-mu Emulator]], and [[Fairlight CMI]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Solida|first1=Scot|title=The 10 most important hardware samplers in history|url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/tech/the-10-most-important-hardware-samplers-in-history-361471|website=Music Radar|accessdate=December 8, 2015}}</ref>
One of the biggest uses of sampling technology was by [[hip-hop music]] [[DJ]]s and performers in the 1980s. Before affordable sampling technology was readily available, DJs would use a technique pioneered by [[Grandmaster Flash]] to manually repeat certain parts in a song by juggling between two separate turntables. This can be considered as an early precursor of sampling. In turn, this [[turntablism]] technique originates from Jamaican [[dub music]] in the 1960s, and was introduced to American hip hop in the 1970s.
In the 2000s, most professional recording studios use digital technologies. In the 2010s, many samplers exist in the digital-only realm. This new generation of digital samplers are capable of reproducing and manipulating sounds. New genres of music have formed which would be impossible without sampling. Advanced sample libraries have made complete performances of [[orchestra]]l compositions possible that sound similar to a live performance.<ref name="Musical Instruments" /> Modern sound libraries allow musicians to have the ability to use the sounds of almost any instrument in their productions.
==MIDI== {{see also|MIDI|}} [[File:Synth rack @ Choking Sun Studio.jpg|thumb|alt=Several rack-mounted synthesizers that share a single controller|MIDI allows multiple instruments to be played from a single controller (often a keyboard, as pictured here), which makes stage setups much more portable. This system fits into a single rack case, but prior to the advent of MIDI. it would have required four separate, heavy full-size keyboard instruments, plus outboard mixing and [[effects unit]]s.]] [[MIDI]] has been the musical instrument industry standard interface since the 1980s through to the present day.<ref name="fact"/> It dates back to June 1981, when [[Roland Corporation]] founder [[Ikutaro Kakehashi]] proposed the concept of standardization between different manufacturers' instruments as well as computers, to [[Oberheim Electronics]] founder [[Tom Oberheim]] and [[Sequential Circuits]] president [[Dave Smith (engineer)|Dave Smith]]. In October 1981, Kakehashi, Oberheim and Smith discussed the concept with representatives from [[Yamaha]], [[Korg]] and [[Kawai (company)|Kawai]].<ref name="chadab5100">{{cite journal|last=Chadabe|first=Joel|authorlink=Joel Chadabe|date=1 May 2000|title=Part IV: The Seeds of the Future|journal=Electronic Musician|publisher=Penton Media|volume=XVI|issue=5|url=http://www.emusician.com/gear/0769/the-electronic-century-part-iv-the-seeds-of-the-future/145415|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928230435/http://www.emusician.com/gear/0769/the-electronic-century-part-iv-the-seeds-of-the-future/145415|archivedate=28 September 2012|df=}}</ref> In 1983, the MIDI standard was unveiled by Kakehashi and Smith.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/news/technical-grammy-award-ikutaro-kakehashi-and-dave-smith|title=Technical GRAMMY Award: Ikutaro Kakehashi And Dave Smith|date=29 January 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/videos/technical-grammy-award-recipients-ikutaro-kakehashi-and-dave-smith-at-special-merit-awards|title=Ikutaro Kakehashi, Dave Smith: Technical GRAMMY Award Acceptance|date=9 February 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
At the [[NAMM]] show in [[Los Angeles]] of 1983, [[MIDI]] was released. A demonstration at the convention showed two previously incompatible analog [[synthesizer]]s, the [[Sequential Circuits|Prophet 600]] and [[Roland Jupiter-6]], communicating with each other, enabling a player to play one keyboard while getting the output from both of them. This was a massive breakthrough in the 1980s, as it allowed synths to be accurately layered in live shows and studio recordings. MIDI enables different electronic instruments and electronic music devices to communicate with each other and with computers. The advent of MIDI spurred a rapid expansion of the sales and production of electronic instruments and music software.
In 1985, several of the top keyboard manufacturers created the [[MIDI Manufacturers Association|MIDI Manufacturers Association (MMA)]]. This newly founded association standardized the MIDI protocol by generating and disseminating all the documents about it. With the development of the MIDI File Format Specification by [[Opcode]], every music software company's [[Music sequencer|MIDI sequencer software]] could read and write each other's files.
Since the 1980s, [[personal computers]] developed and became the ideal system for utilizing the vast potential of [[MIDI]]. This has created a large consumer market for software such as MIDI-equipped [[electronic keyboard]]s, [[Music sequencer|MIDI sequencers]] and [[Digital Audio Workstation]]s. With universal MIDI protocols, electronic keyboards, sequencers, and drum machines can all be connected together.
Some universally accepted varieties of [[Comparison of MIDI editors and sequencers|MIDI software applications]] include music instruction software, MIDI sequencing software, music notation software, [[hard disk]] recording/editing software, patch editor/sound library software, computer-assisted composition software, and [[Software synthesizer|virtual instruments]]. Current developments in computer hardware and specialized software continue to expand MIDI applications.
==Computers in music technology==
Computer and synthesizer technology joining together changed the way music is made, and is one of the fastest changing aspects of music technology today. [[Max Mathews|Dr. Max Matthews]], a telecommunications engineer at [[Bell Telephone Laboratories]]' Acoustic and Behavioural Research Department, is responsible for some of the first digital music technology in the 50s. [[Max Mathews|Dr. Matthews]] also pioneered a cornerstone of music technology; [[Analog-to-digital converter|analog to digital conversion]].
The first generation of professional commercially available computer music instruments, or [[workstation]]s as some companies later called them, were very sophisticated elaborate systems that cost a great deal of money when they first appeared. They ranged from $25,000 to $200,000.<ref name="Electronic Music Pioneers" /> The two most popular were the [[Fairlight CMI|Fairlight]], and the [[Synclavier]].
It was not until the advent of [[MIDI]] that [[general-purpose computer]]s started to play a role in music production. Following the widespread adoption of MIDI, computer-based [[Comparison of MIDI editors and sequencers|MIDI editors and sequencers]] were developed. MIDI-to-[[CV/Gate]] converters were then used to enable [[analogue synthesizer]]s to be controlled by a MIDI sequencer.<ref name="russ2012">{{cite book | last = Russ |first = Martin | year = 2012 | title = Sound Synthesis and Sampling | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=X9h5AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA192 | publisher = [[CRC Press]] | ISBN = 1136122141 | page = 192 | accessdate = 26 April 2017}}</ref>
Reduced prices in [[personal computer]]s caused the masses to turn away from the more expensive [[workstation]]s. Advancements in technology have increased the speed of hardware processing and the capacity of memory units. Software developers write new, more powerful programs for sequencing, recording, notating, and mastering music.
==2000s== [[Music sequencer]] software, such as [[Pro Tools]], [[Logic Audio]] and many others, are the most widely used form of contemporary music technology in the 2000s. Such programs allow the user to record acoustic sounds with a [[microphone]], [[audio mixing|mix tracks]] record or [[MIDI]] musical sequences, which may then be organized along a timeline and edited on a [[flat-panel display]] of a [[computer]] or [[Digital Audio Workstation]]. Musical segments recorded on can be copied and duplicated ad infinitum, without any loss of fidelity or added noise (a major contrast from [[analog recording]], in which every copy leads to a loss of fidelity and added noise). Digital music can be edited and processed using a multitude of audio effects. [[Contemporary classical music]] sometimes uses computer-generated sounds, either pre-recorded or generated/manipulated live, in conjunction or [[wikt:juxtaposition]] with classical [[Acoustic music|acoustic instruments]] like the cello or violin. Classical and other notated types of music are frequently written on [[scorewriter]] software.
Many musicians and artists use 'patcher' type programmes, such as [[Pure Data|Pd]], [[Bidule]], [[Max/MSP]], [[Kyma (sound design language)]] and [[Audiomulch]] as well as (or instead of) [[digital audio workstation]]s or sequencers and there are still a significant number of people using more "traditional" software only approaches such as [[CSound]] or the [[Composers Desktop Project]]. Music technology includes many forms of music reproduction. Music and sound technology refer to the use of sound engineering in a commercial, experimental or amateur hobbyist manner. Music technology and sound technology may sometimes be classed as the same thing, but they actually refer to different fields of work. Sound engineering refers primarily to the use of sound technology for [[sound recording]] or in [[sound reinforcement system]]s used in concerts and live shows.

== Awards & results ==
=== Awards === In 2016 two University of London academic awards were given to NCH London students, including the [[Sir Charles Harris award]].
In 2015 New College of the Humanities won the Courses and Lecturers category at the What Uni Student Choice Awards (WUSCA) and came fourth in the category of University of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whatuni.com/degrees/student-awards-winners/2015.html|title=WUSCA Courses and Lecturers|last=|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whatuni.com/degrees/student-awards-winners/2015.html|title=University of the Year|last=|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2015 NCH students won three of the University of London's academic awards, including the Sir Charles Harris award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://view.joomag.com/university-of-london-international-programmes-graduation-2015-graduation-2015/0540571001479387047?page=75|title=Academic Awards|last=|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Results === In the 2017 National Student Survey, NCH achieved student satisfaction scores above Russell Group universities and London universities, beating London members of the Russell Group in most categories.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/2017/08/09/nch-leads-london-institutions-nss-2017/|title=NCH London leads London universities|last=|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
In May 2014 it was reported that independent research that replicated the annual HEPI academic experience survey showed that the College's academic experience had exceeded the expectations of 63% of its students. This was more than twice the comparative statistic (28%) for [[Russell Group]] university students of humanities and social sciences in the HEPI 2014 annual student experience survey. The same research also showed that NCH students experienced 40% more contact time than their peers at Russell Group universities, that they completed twice as many assignments, and that they received feedback on their assignments in person more than twice as often.
== Degrees & teaching ==
===Courses=== The college offers tuition for 53 undergraduate programmes featuring major and minor options in Art History, Creative Writing, Economics, English, History, Law, Philosophy and Politics and International Relations, as well as a single honours Law LLB, and a Philosophy, Politics and Economics BA. In addition, its undergraduate students complete courses in applied ethics, critical reasoning, science literacy, and a professional development programme.<ref>https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/hubs/undergraduate/</ref> The science literacy course includes as its teachers, Richard Dawkins teaching evolution, Steven Pinker lecturing about the brain, and Daniel C Dennett lecturing on consciousness.<ref>https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/science-literacy/</ref>
===Teaching=== Students experience more than 13 contact hours per week, including regular one-to-one and small group tutorials.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/NCH-Contact-hours-graphic-1.pdf|title=Average weekly contact hours NCH London|last=|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=nchlondon|access-date=}}</ref> In the 2017 National Student Survey, NCH achieved student satisfaction scores above Russell Group universities and London universities, beating London members of the elite Russell Group in 26 out of 27 categories.<ref name=":0" />
In May 2014 it was reported that independent research that replicated the annual HEPI academic experience survey showed that the College's academic experience had exceeded the expectations of 63% of its students. This was more than twice the comparative statistic (28%) for [[Russell Group]] university students of humanities and social sciences in the HEPI 2014 annual student experience survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hepi.ac.uk/2014/05/21/hepi-hea-2014-student-experience-survey/|title=HEPI/HEA 2014 Student Experience Survey: "vital questions for universities, students and Government"|date=21 May 2014|publisher=Higher Education Policy Institute|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> The same research also showed that NCH students experienced 40% more contact time than their peers at Russell Group universities, that they completed twice as many assignments, and that they received feedback on their assignments in person more than twice as often.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nchum.org/undergraduate-study/why-nch|title=Why NCH?|publisher=New College of the Humanities|accessdate=29 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529234219/https://www.nchum.org/undergraduate-study/why-nch#|archive-date=29 May 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Background==
===History=== [[File:AC Grayling 2.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[A. C. Grayling]], professor of philosophy at Birkbeck College until June 2011, secured NCH's funding.]] The college models itself on [[liberal arts college]]s in the United States, such as [[Amherst College]].<ref name=GrimstonJune52011>Grimston, Jack. "Top dons create new Oxbridge," ''The Sunday Times'', 5 June 2011.</ref> Initial reports said it aimed to offer an education to rival that of [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]],<ref name=TelegraphJune52011>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/8557555/New-university-to-rival-Oxbridge-will-charge-18000-a-year.html "New university to rival Oxbridge will charge £18,000 a year"], ''The Sunday Telegraph'', 5 June 2011.</ref> but Grayling said this had been blown out of proportion by press hyperbole.<ref name=MalikJune92011>Malik, Shiv. [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/09/grayling-abused-over-new-college-plans?intcmp=239 "AC Grayling complains of abuse over creation of elite New College"], ''The Guardian'', 9 June 2011: "All these people are partners in the enterprise. ... They are people whose advice and expertise and experience will be provided to us because they are actual shareholders in the institution." * For the list of partners and staff, see [http://www.nchum.org/who-we-are "Who we are"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608234516/http://www.nchum.org/who-we-are# |date=8 June 2011 }}, New College of the Humanities, accessed 10 June 2011.{{dead link|date=February 2015}}</ref> He said he had the idea for the college years ago when he was admissions tutor for an [[Oxbridge]] college, and was turning down 12 good applicants for every successful one.<ref name=JohnsonJune62011>Johnson, Boris. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/columnists/borisjohnson/8558621/At-last-an-Oxbridge-for-those-who-cant-get-into-Oxbridge.html "At last, an Oxbridge for those who can’t get into Oxbridge"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 6 June 2011.</ref> Grayling himself completed his first degree in philosophy in the 1970s as a University of London external student.<ref>Lacey, Hester. [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/738df0c8-9177-11e0-b1ea-00144feab49a.html#axzz1OvYJMIyS "The Inventory: Anthony Grayling"], ''The Financial Times'', 10 June 2011.</ref> He argues that there is not enough elite university provision in the UK, leading thousands of British students to study in the United States instead.<ref name=JohnsonJune62011/> He told ''The Independent'' that the headmaster of [[Winchester College]], an independent secondary school, had said many of his best students failed to get into Oxbridge because of government pressure to increase the number of students from state schools.<ref>Lawson, Dominic. [https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/dominic-lawson/dominic-lawson-a-private-sector-oxbridge-not-exactly-2293915.html "A private sector Oxbridge? Not exactly"], ''The Independent'', 7 June 2011.</ref> Grayling has criticised English state examinations, arguing that A-levels do not measure ability adequately.<ref>Hurst, Greg; Sugden, Joanna; Sylvester, Rachel; and Thomson, Alice. "New university founder condemns A levels," ''The Sunday Times'', 11 June 2011.</ref>
Grayling said [[David Willetts]], the universities minister, was told of the project in 2010, and appeared enthusiastic.<ref name="GrimstonJune122011">Grimston, Jack. "Minister encouraged launch of elite college," ''The Sunday Times'', 12 June 2011.</ref> NCH Limited was first named Grayling Hall Limited (after AC Grayling and Peter Hall), incorporated in July 2010 and registered at an address in [[Peckham]], south London. The name was changed to New College of the Humanities in February 2011.<ref>For registration and change of name, see [http://www.jordans.co.uk/CompanyIndex/n/ne/new/07317195/new_college_of_the_humanities_limited.html "New College of the Humanities Limited"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809132756/http://www.jordans.co.uk/CompanyIndex/n/ne/new/07317195/new_college_of_the_humanities_limited.html# |date=9 August 2011 }}, Jordan's Business Information Services, accessed 8 June 2011. * [http://www.nchum.org/terms-and-conditions "Terms and conditions"], New College of the Humanities, accessed 8 June 2011.{{Dead link |date=December 2016}}</ref> The warden of [[New College, Oxford]], who asked Grayling to change the name again to prevent confusion with the Oxford college, said other names Grayling had previously considered were Bloomsbury College and Erasmus College.<ref name=BoothJune82011>Booth, Robert. [https://www.theguardian.com/global/2011/jun/08/new-arts-college-ac-grayling "Oxford tries to throw book at new arts college set up by AC Grayling"], ''The Guardian'', 8 June 2011.</ref>
From September 2012 to September 2015<ref>[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/southampton-solent-validate-£18k-new-college-humanities-degrees]</ref> it offered tuition<ref name=BBCJune52011>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13659394 "British academics launch £18,000 college in London"], BBC News, 5 June 2011.</ref> in [[economics]], English, [[history]], law and [[philosophy]] and politics and international relations for undergraduate degrees with the [[University of London International Programme]]. It now runs its own degree programmes, modelled on American [[liberal arts college]] courses where students study a major and a minor subject, validated by [[Southampton Solent University]]. It continues to offer a law degree through the University of London.<ref name=THESotonSolent/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/about-us/|title=About Us|website=New College of the Humanities|accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref> In addition, it requires all undergraduate students to work towards a "Diploma of New College of the Humanities" by completing courses drawn from applied ethics, critical reasoning, science literacy and LAUNCH, its professional development programme.<ref>[https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/diploma/ The NCH Diploma]</ref>
In 2016 NCH announced that it would be offering its first postgraduate qualification, the Historical Research and Public History MA starting in September 2016. This Masters programme has been designed by Dr [[Suzannah Lipscomb]], Head of Faculty and Senior Lecturer in Early Modern History. It is validated by Swansea University.<ref name="timeshighereducation.com">[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/new-college-humanities-offers-its-first-ma New College of the Humanities offers its first MA], ''[[Times Higher Education]]'', April 17, 2016</ref> In 2017 the College launched three additional master's degrees, the MA Economic Policy & Communication, MSc Global Politics, and MA Philosophy.<ref>https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/hubs/postgraduate-study-at-nch/</ref>
The college uses its own building, ''The Registry'', and some of the [[University of London|University of London's]] teaching and student facilities, including [[Senate House Library]] and the [[Institute of Advanced Legal Studies]], all in the [[Bloomsbury]] district of London.<ref name=VasagarJune62011>Vasagar, Jeevan. [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/06/ac-grayling-private-university "Doubts raised over the financial model of AC Grayling's private university"], ''The Guardian'', 6 June 2011.</ref><ref name=BoothJune62011>Booth, Richard. [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/06/ac-grayling-private-university-syllabus "AC Grayling's private university accused of copying syllabuses"], ''The Guardian'', 6 June 2011. * [http://www.londoninternational.ac.uk/media/press_releases/new_college_humanities.shtml "University of London statement regarding New College of the Humanities"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610040538/http://www.londoninternational.ac.uk/media/press_releases/new_college_humanities.shtml# |date=10 June 2011 }}, ''University of London'', 6 June 2011.</ref>
The College's foundation attracted a substantial response in the UK, and a significant amount of adverse publicity, where most higher education institutions are publicly funded. London's mayor, [[Boris Johnson]], welcomed it as a bold experiment, while ''The Times'' argued that higher education has been a closed shop in the UK for too long.<ref>Johnson, Boris. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/columnists/borisjohnson/8558621/At-last-an-Oxbridge-for-those-who-cant-get-into-Oxbridge.html "At last, an Oxbridge for those who can’t get into Oxbridge"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 6 June 2011. * "Experiments in Teaching," ''The Times'', 8 June 2011.</ref> There was an angry reaction from sections of the academic community. Complaints included that NCH had copied the course descriptions of the University of London's international programmes on its website; was offering the same syllabus with a significantly higher price tag; and that the senior academics involved with the project would in fact do very little of the teaching.<ref name=BakerJune92011>Baker, Simon. [http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=26&storycode=416440&c=1 "Grayling's plans for tutorials with the stars receive poor notices from disgruntled critics"], ''Times Higher Education'', 9 June 2011.</ref>
Academics and Administrators within the British academic world have in recent years alluded to the College's for-profit agenda, highlight the College's high tuition fees, the corporate structure as a [[Limited company]], and the membership of the College's board.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The £54,000 degree: how well is AC Grayling's college doing?|url = https://www.theguardian.com/education/2013/oct/26/degree-ac-grayling-university-new-college|website = The Guardian|accessdate = 2015-10-09|first = Amelia|last = Gentleman}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = NCH Board - New College of the Humanities|url = https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/nch-board/|website = New College of the Humanities|accessdate = 2015-10-09|language = en}}</ref>
===Funding and governance=== Initial "seed capital" of £200,000 for the project was provided, according to British newspaper ''The Guardian'', by the financier Peter Hall.<ref>Hughes, Solomon., Evans, Robert and Shepherd, Jessica. [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/16/tory-party-donor-peter-hall-grayling-university Tory party donor Peter Hall funded Anthony Grayling's university: Financier with radical Conservative libertarian views says he provided £200,000 to 'breathe life into the idea'] ''The Guardian'', Thursday, 16 June 2011, accessed Nov 2011.</ref>
£10 million in [[private equity firm|private equity funding]] was subsequently raised to cover costs for two years, with the expectation that NCH would break even by the third.<ref name="VasagarJune62011"/> One third of the enterprise is owned by 14 senior academics, including Grayling, and the rest by private investors, including a couple from Switzerland and three British businessmen—Jeremy Gibbs, Matthew Batstone and [[Roy W. Brown]].<ref name=MalikJune92011/> Cavendish Corporate Finance LLP were the corporate financiers hired by NCH Ltd and raised this £10 million from a range of private investors including a number of prominent individuals from the world of business and finance.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cavendish.com/news/cavendish-corporate-finance-successfully-leads-the-start-up-capital-fundraising-to-create-the-new-college-of-the-humanities# |title=Cavendish Corporate Finance: Cavendish Corporate Finance successfully leads the start-up capital fundraising to create the New College of the Humanities, published 12 June 2011 (Accessed November 2011) |access-date=29 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426010840/http://www.cavendish.com/news/cavendish-corporate-finance-successfully-leads-the-start-up-capital-fundraising-to-create-the-new-college-of-the-humanities# |archive-date=26 April 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Gibbs, former chairman of Futuretalk plc, deputy chairman of Scientific Digital Imaging plc and director of Cambridge Venture Management (2000) Ltd, was registered as the CEO,<ref>[http://www.levelbusiness.com/doc/person/uk/05279257 "Jeremy Stephen Gibbs"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223064310/http://www.levelbusiness.com/doc/person/uk/05279257# |date=23 February 2015 }}, LevelBusiness, accessed 8 June 2011. * [https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/companyOfficers?symbol=SDIS.L "Scientific Digital Imaging PLC"], Reuters, accessed 11 June 2011. * [http://www.nchum.org/who-we-are/non-academic-staff "Non-academic staff"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609003613/http://www.nchum.org/who-we-are/non-academic-staff# |date=9 June 2011 }}, New College of the Humanities, accessed 11 June 2011. * [http://www.scientificdigitalimaging.com/Jeremy_Gibbs.pdf "Jeremy Gibbs"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325143501/http://www.scientificdigitalimaging.com/Jeremy_Gibbs.pdf# |date=25 March 2012 }}, Scientific Digital Imaging, accessed 11 June 2011.{{Dead link |date=December 2016}}</ref> while Charles Watson, chairman of the PR firm Financial Dynamics, was named as non-executive chairman. <ref name=BoothJune52011>Booth, Robert. [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/05/new-college-dawkins-grayling-ferguson "New university gathers top academics to teach £18,000-a-year degrees"], ''The Guardian'', 5 June 2011. * Also see [http://www.fd.com/Homepage/PeopleProfile.aspx?UserID=e108c89b-56e8-4959-8f1f-2f23bdc2ecbe "Charles Watson"], Financial Dynamics, accessed 5 June 2011. * Wicks, Nikki. [http://www.prweek.com/uk/channel/CityandCorporate/article/1073526/FD%27s%20former%20CEO%20is%20chairing%20London%27s%20new%20controversial%20university%20college/ "FD's former CEO Charles Watson to chair controversial university college"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609224642/http://www.prweek.com/uk/channel/CityandCorporate/article/1073526/FD's%20former%20CEO%20is%20chairing%20London's%20new%20controversial%20university%20college# |date=9 June 2011 }}, ''PR Week'', 6 June 2011.</ref>
Batstone and Brown are non-executive directors; Batstone is the former marketing chief of the Economist Group and a trustee of [[Bedales School|Bedales]], an independent secondary school, and Brown is the founder of Metier Management Systems.<ref name=BoothJune52011/>
The 14 academic partners, also referred to as ''The Professoriate'', were announced as:<ref name=faculty-staff>[http://www.nchum.org/faculty-staff "Faculty and Staff"], New College of the Humanities, accessed 10 June 2011.</ref> * philosophers [[A. C. Grayling]], [[Simon Blackburn]] and [[Peter Singer]] * historians [[David Cannadine]] and [[Niall Ferguson]] * economist [[Partha Dasgupta]] * scientists [[Richard Dawkins]] (will be Professor of Evolutionary Biology), [[Steve Jones (biologist)|Steve Jones]] (was to have been Professor of Biological Sciences),<ref>Jones has been reported in ''The Telegraph'', 16 April, as having had a change of heart and has "amicably" withdrawn. He did not "rule out giving the odd talk" at the NCH. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/9205515/A-C-Grayling-puts-a-brave-face-on-Steve-Joness-withdrawal-from-his-university.html Walker, Tim (2012) A C Grayling puts a brave face on Steve Jones's withdrawal from his university: A C Grayling's controversial New College of the Humanities suffers a setback as Professor Steve Jones withdraws as a founding partner, ''The Telegraph'', 16 Apr 2012] (Accessed 20 April 2012). </ref> [[Steven Pinker]] * legal scholars [[Ronald Dworkin]] and [[Adrian Zuckerman]] * literary critic [[Christopher Ricks]].
Since the launch of the college, professors [[Vernon Bogdanor]], [[Daniel C Dennett]], [[Rebecca Goldstein]], Roger Halson, [[Howard Jacobson]], Simon May, Barbara McDonald, Stephen Neal, [[Sir Trevor Nunn]] and [[Christopher Peacocke]] have also lectured at the college.<ref name="ReferenceA">https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/faculty/</ref>
A charitable trust was established, the New College of the Humanities Trust, consisting of Grayling, Gibbs, Batstone, Watson and Brown.<ref name=trust>[https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/scholarships/#page-section-3 "New College of the Humanities Trust"], New College of the Humanities, accessed 5 May 2016.</ref> This provides scholarships based on academic merit, and means-tested bursaries to students with sufficient academic calibre who would not be able to study at the college without further financial support.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/home-fees/|title=Bursaries and Scholarships NCH London|last=|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
===First cohort=== The first cohort consisted of around 60 students, primarily from [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|independent]] schools; one in five of the college's offers have gone to state-school students. College staff made 130 visits to schools (21 to state schools) to attract applications.<ref>Jeevan Vasagar, [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2012/apr/20/private-schools-dominate-grayling-college "Private-school pupils will dominate elite college set up by AC Grayling"], ''The Guardian'', 20 April 2012</ref><ref>Robert Booth, [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2012/sep/18/ac-graylings-university-open-60-students "AC Grayling's private university to open with just 60 students"], ''The Guardian'', 18 September 2012</ref> They graduated in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/2015/07/22/our-summer-summary-new-graduates-and-new-opportunities/|title=Graduates|last=|first=|date=4 December 2017|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==College structure==
===Facilities and fees=== [[File:Bedford Square 2.jpg|thumb|The Registry, Bedford Square]]
The college has a building called ''The Registry'' in [[Bedford Square]] where the one-to-one and small group tutorials take place. The Registry also contains rooms for most lectures. In addition, the college's students have access to the University's facilities, including Senate House Library <ref>https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/living-in-london/libraries/</ref> and Student Central.<ref>https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/living-in-london/the-campus/#page-section-5</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/08/university-london-independent-college-humanities "University of London's independent stance"], letter from the dean of University of London International Programmes, ''The Guardian'', 8 June 2011.</ref> It block-books rooms for its first-year students with student accommodation providers in Bloomsbury, Westminster, St Pancras and Tufnell Park.<ref>https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/accommodation/</ref> NCH has offered classes since October 2012,<ref name="BBCJune52011" /> its annual fees are £9,250.<ref>https://www.nchlondon.ac.uk/funding/home-fees/</ref>
==Reception== Grayling said he had received 900 expressions of interest from potential students and 80 job applications in the first week.<ref name=GrimstonJune122011/> Britain's former prime minister, [[Tony Blair]], endorsed it;<ref name=LongJune122011>Long, Camilla. "AC Grayling: Is it safe to come out now?", ''The Sunday Times'', 12 June 2011.</ref> and London's mayor, [[Boris Johnson]], called it the boldest experiment in higher education in the UK since the foundation in 1983 of the [[University of Buckingham]], the UK's first private university; he wrote that it showed the way ahead for academics demoralized by government interference with admissions procedures and "scapegoated for the weaknesses of the schools."<ref name=JohnsonJune62011/> ''The Times'' argued that higher education has been a closed shop in the UK for too long, that all over the world there are excellent universities run independently of the state, and that in its conception NCH is teaching by example.<ref>"Experiments in Teaching," ''The Times'', 8 June 2011.</ref> ''The Economist'' wrote that there is a market for the idea because of the increasing number of qualified British students who fail to get into their university of choice, in part because of pressure on the top universities from the [[Office for Fair Access]] to increase the number of students from state schools; they added that "a 'toffs’ college' of well-heeled Oxbridge near-misses is a provocative concept."<ref name=EconomistJune92011>[http://www.economist.com/node/18805758 "One very New College, at a price"], ''The Economist'', 9 June 2011.</ref> The Harvard historian Niall Ferguson, one of the college's partners, said he had read the criticism of NCH with incredulity: "Anyone who cares about the humanities will be cheering Anthony Grayling."<ref name=GrimstonJune122011/>
The news triggered accusations of elitism. Literary critic [[Terry Eagleton]] called the college "odious," arguing that it was taking advantage of a crumbling university system to make money;<ref>Eagleton, Terry. [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jun/06/ac-graylings-new-private-univerity-is-odious "AC Grayling's new private University is odious"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 6 June 2011.</ref> Grayling responded that Eagleton himself teaches a few weeks a year at the [[University of Notre Dame]] in Indiana, USA, a private - though non-profit - university.<ref name=MalikJune92011/><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110616035525/http://english.nd.edu/faculty/profiles/eagleton/ Terry Eagleton], Excellence in English Distinguished Visitor, [[University of Notre Dame]], June 16, 2011</ref> Lawyer [[David Allen Green]], writing in the ''New Statesman'', described NCH as a "sham" and a "branding exercise with purchased celebrity endorsements and a PR-driven website."<ref name="GreenJune72011">Green, David Allen. [http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/david-allen-green/2011/06/college-humanities-students "Grayling's Folly is falling down"], ''New Statesman'', 7 June 2011.</ref> Several academics complained in a letter to ''The Guardian'' that its creation was a setback for the campaign against the [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|current government's]] policy of commercializing education, and were joined by 34 of Grayling's former colleagues at Birkbeck, who questioned how much teaching the college's 14 academic partners would actually do.<ref>For the letter, see [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/07/new-college-humanities-gated-intellectual-community "The shame of this 'gated intellectual community'"], Letters to the editor, ''The Guardian'', 7 June 2011. * For the 34 former colleagues, see [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/14/birkbeck-academics-oppose-grayling-college "Why we Birkbeck Academics oppose Grayling's New College"], ''The Guardian'', 15 June 2011.</ref> [[Terence Kealey]], then Vice-Chancellor of the University of Buckingham, suggested it was dangerous to have a university funded by private equity, citing the possible collapse in 2011 of [[Southern Cross Healthcare (United Kingdom)|Southern Cross]] private nursing homes.<ref>Kealey, Terence. [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/columnists/article3054167.ece "Don't call these people Ivy League pioneers"], ''The Times'', 7 June 2011.</ref>
[[Toby Young]] argued in ''The Daily Telegraph'' that the reaction was part of a left-wing campaign to retain state control over education, involving, he wrote, public sector unions, university lecturers, and the Socialist Workers Party.<ref>[http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/tobyyoung/100091198/welcome-to-the-fight-professor-grayling/ "Welcome to the fight, Professor Grayling"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 8 June 2011.</ref> [[Simon Jenkins]] wrote that the country's professors, lecturers and student trade unionists were "united in arms against what they most hate and fear: academic celebrity, student fees, profit and loss, one-to-one tutorials and America."<ref>Jenkins, Simon. [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jun/09/ac-grayling-caricatured-british-university-fuming "AC Grayling has caricatured British universities. No wonder they're fuming"], ''The Guardian'', 9 June 2011.</ref>
Grayling responded to the criticism by arguing that NCH is trying to keep humanities teaching alive. He said he felt persecuted by the negative reaction: "My whole record, everything I have written, is turned on its head. Now I am a bastard capitalist. It is really upsetting. ... Education is a public good and we should be spending more on it and it shouldn't be necessary to do this, but standing on the sidelines moaning and wailing is not an option."<ref name="VasagarBoothJune72011">Vasagar, Jeevan and Booth, Robert. [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/06/ac-grayling-private-university-syllabus "AC Grayling's private university accused of copying syllabuses"], ''The Guardian'', 7 June 2011.</ref> In a 2012 interview, Grayling also responded to claims that the college was "elitist": "There is nothing wrong with being elite as long as you are not exclusive. You want your surgeon or airline pilot to have been trained at an elite institution."<ref name="NewHumanist">{{Cite journal|url=http://newhumanist.org.uk/2859/saving-our-universities-new-humanist-interviews-ac-grayling|title=Saving our universities? New Humanist interviews AC Grayling|first=Caspar|last=Melville|publisher=New Humanist|volume=127|number=5|year=2012}}</ref>
A dozen protesters heckled Grayling at [[Foyles]] bookshop in London on 7 June 2011 during a debate about cuts to arts funding, one of them shouting that he had "no right to speak." A protester let off a smoke bomb, and 100 people were evacuated from the store.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationnews/8562531/AC-Grayling-forced-to-flee-smoke-bomb-protest-at-Foyles-debate-on-private-university.html "AC Grayling forced to flee smoke bomb protest at Foyles debate on private university"], Andrew Hough, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 7 June 2011</ref> Later in the week police removed protesters from a [[British Humanist Association]] talk by Richard Dawkins at the [[Institute of Education]].<ref name=GrimstonJune122011/>
In January 2012, the [[United Kingdom Intellectual Property Office|UK's Intellectual Property Office]] objected to the college name being registered as a trademark because of possible confusion with [[New College, Oxford]].<ref name ="BBC 2012 01 23">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-16681870 Private college faces objection in trade mark bid], BBC News, 23 January 2012</ref>
